Jan 06, 2026

SCOTT SAFFORD APPOINTED AS WAXAHACHIE FIRE-RESCUE CHIEF

The City of Waxahachie is pleased to announce the appointment of Scott Safford as the new Chief of Waxahachie Fire-Rescue. Chief Safford, a dedicated member of the fire department for 21 years, brings extensive experience, leadership, and dedication to the role. Throughout his distinguished career, Chief Safford has served the Waxahachie community in various capacities, from firefighter to Battalion Chief and, most recently, as Interim Chief. His educational achievements include a Bachelor‚Äôs Degree in Fire Administration from Texas A&M San Antonio and graduation as an Executive Fire Officer from the Texas Fire Chiefs‚Äô Academy. He also earned his Leadership in Supervision certificate from the prestigious National Fire Academy in Maryland, along with numerous specialty certifications from the State of Texas.

Chief Safford is committed to furthering his education and keeping the Waxahachie Fire-Rescue Department at the forefront of fire service advancements. His dedication to the safety and well-being of both the community and his fellow firefighters remains steadfast.

Chief Safford shared, ‚ÄúI truly believe that God created me to serve others, and I am passionate about serving our community and firefighters to ensure their safety and well-being.‚Äù Chief Safford and his wife, Courtney, have been married for 14 years and are proud parents to their son, Zane, and daughter, Ryann.

City Manager Ricky Boyd expressed his enthusiasm for the appointment, stating, ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to welcome Chief Safford to this new leadership role. His deep roots in our community, extensive experience, and proven leadership make him the ideal choice to guide Waxahachie Fire-Rescue into the future. We look forward to the positive impact he will continue to make for our city and our residents.‚Äù

The City of Waxahachie congratulates Chief Safford on his new role and anticipates ongoing excellence in fire and emergency services under his leadership.

Dec 18, 2025

PUBLIC MEETING PROCESS CHANGES

On Monday, December 15, the City Council adopted an ordinance regarding Rules of Procedure for meetings. The ordinance establishes clear, consistent rules for how City Council meetings and public hearings are conducted. These rules apply to the City Council as well as all City boards and commissions.

What This Means for Residents
Clear Public Comment Process

  • Residents may speak during the Public Comments portion of City Council meetings about items not on the agenda.
  • Speakers must sign up:
    • In person at least 10 minutes before the meeting, or
    • Online by 4:00 p.m. on the day of the meeting.
  • Each speaker is allowed up to 3 minutes.
  • Speakers may speak once per meeting, per item, and cannot give unused time to others.

Written Comments Welcome

  • Residents who prefer not to speak may submit written comments.
  • These comments may be read or summarized by the Mayor and included in the meeting record.

Public Hearings Made More Consistent

  • Public hearings now follow a standard process so everyone has a fair opportunity to be heard.
  • Applicants and appellants are given time to present, followed by public testimony.
  • Public speakers are limited to 3 minutes each.
  • The Mayor may adjust time limits when many people wish to speak or an item is complex.

Orderly and Respectful Meetings

  • Everyone attending meetings is expected to be respectful.
  • Disruptive behavior, personal attacks, or profanity may result in removal from the meeting.

How Decisions Are Made

  • State law limits City Council from debating or voting on topics raised during Public Comments.
  • Issues raised by residents may be placed on a future agenda for discussion.

Why This Was Done

These changes are intended to:

  • Improve consistency and fairness.
  • Ensure meetings run smoothly and efficiently.
  • Provide clear guidance for public participation.

When It Takes Effect

The new rules will take effect on February 2, 2026.

For more information on attending or participating in City Council meetings, visit the City‚Äôs website or contact the City Secretary‚Äôs office at Citysecretary@waxahachie.com.

Please visit the Public Meeting Participation website page for details.

Dec 08, 2025

CITY OF WAXAHACHIE ANNOUNCES APPOINTMENT OF RICKY BOYD AS NEW CITY MANAGER
The City of Waxahachie is proud to announce that, on Monday, December 8, the Waxahachie City Council unanimously voted to appoint Ricky Boyd as City Manager. This decision reflects the Council‚Äôs dedication to experienced leadership and to the ongoing managed growth of the community while maintaining a balanced, responsible budget. Ricky Boyd is a long-time public servant with deep roots in the community. He holds a Bachelor of Science in Fire Science from Columbia Southern University and an Associate of Applied Science from Navarro Junior College. Boyd‚Äôs career spans over four decades in public service, including:
 
‚Ä¢ Interim City Manager, City of Waxahachie (July 2025 ‚Äì December 2025)
‚Ä¢ Fire Chief, City of Waxahachie (November 2012 ‚Äì July 2025)
‚Ä¢ Assistant Fire Chief, City of Irving (June 1987 ‚Äì November 2012)
‚Ä¢ Firefighter, City of Lancaster (November 1984 ‚Äì June 1987)
 
Boyd‚Äôs professional development includes key certifications such as Municipal Leadership, Head of Department, Suppression & Prevention; Texas Fire Chiefs Academy Graduate; Master Firefighter; and Incident Commander & Incident Safety Officer. His proven leadership and dedication to Waxahachie have made him a respected leader in the community.
 
Mayor Billie Wallace expressed her confidence in Boyd‚Äôs appointment, stating, "Ricky Boyd has demonstrated strong and unwavering leadership to Waxahachie throughout his career. His hands-on decision-making, transparency, and encouragement of communication between all City staff and City Council, along with his proven commitment to public service, make him the right choice to guide our city forward. We are excited to welcome him as City Manager and look forward to continued progress under his stewardship.‚Äù
 
Upon his appointment, Ricky Boyd shared, ‚ÄúI am deeply honored by the trust the City Council has placed in me. Waxahachie is my home, and I am committed to working alongside our talented staff, leaders, and residents to ensure a bright future for our city. I also want to take the opportunity to thank my wife and family for their support throughout my career. Most of all, I‚Äôd like to thank the Lord for his many blessings.‚Äù
 
Ricky Boyd will assume his duties as City Manager immediately, leading the City‚Äôs daily operations and partnering with the City Council to advance Waxahachie‚Äôs strategic goals.

Nov 12, 2025

CITY OFFICES CLOSED FOR THANKSGIVING HOLIDAY
City Offices Closed for Thanksgiving Holiday
City offices will be closed on Thursday, November 27th, and Friday, November 28th, in observance of the Thanksgiving holiday. For non-emergency needs during this time, please call the Waxahachie Police Department at 469-309-4400. For emergencies, please dial 911.

Citizens Convenience Station Closed for Thanksgiving Holiday

The Citizens Convenience Station will be closed from Thursday, November 27th, through Sunday, November 30th, in observance of the Thanksgiving holiday. The facility will reopen on Tuesday, December 2nd, and resume normal operating hours (Tuesday through Saturday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., closed Sunday & Monday) located at 499 Lions Park Road.

Citizens using the facility must bring a driver‚Äôs license or another form of identification and proof of residency (water bill, garbage bill, or tax statement). For additional questions regarding the Convenience Station, please call 469-309-4270.

Thanksgiving Trash Schedule
Residential trash service will not run on Thursday, November 27th. Residential trash service that would typically pick up on Thursday will run on Friday (the following day). For additional information, please call Waste Connections at 972-289-6714.

Doors will open at 9:30 a.m., with the program beginning promptly at 10:00 a.m. The event will take place at the Waxahachie Civic Center, 2000 Civic Center Lane.

Sep 11, 2025

MESSAGE FROM THE MAYOR

I am deeply saddened by the death of Charlie Kirk. My heart aches for his family and loved ones, who will never celebrate holidays with him again. I sincerely hope the person responsible is found and justice is served.

Every murder, where an innocent life is taken, is difficult for us to understand. Every murder we hear and read about, where an innocent life is taken, shakes most of us to the core. There is just no reason for it, and it sends us all into a state of shock.

The death of Charlie Kirk is heartbreaking, along with all the other senseless deaths that have occurred before him and, unfortunately, will happen again in the future. I pray that we all come together, look beyond our differences, and practice compassion for one another. We don't all have to agree, but we should strive to be decent and show love to others whenever we can.

It doesn't matter which state these horrific crimes occur in; they still impact us the same. Can we all agree that we can do better? I commit to continuing to work on becoming a better version of myself, even if I disagree with someone else's views or ideas. It‚Äôs never too late to improve and choose a better path forward.

Mayor Billie Wallace
 City of Waxahachie

Aug 29, 2025

CREDIT CARD FEES TO BEGIN SOON

Effective November 1, 2025, there will be a 3.95% processing fee applied to all credit card payments, including those made through AutoPay.

To avoid this fee, customers may pay using:

  • E-check (online)
  • Check (in person or by mail)
  • Cash (in person)
To pay online, please visit the Utility Billing page.

Please also note that American Express will no longer be accepted starting November 1, 2025.

For questions, please contact Utility Billing at ub@waxahachie.com or 469-309-4170.

Jul 28, 2025

CITY OF WAXAHACHIE ANNOUNCES 175TH BIRTHDAY BASH: A HISTORIC CELEBRATION

Waxahachie, TX ‚Äî The City of Waxahachie is thrilled to invite residents and visitors alike to the 175th Birthday Bash, a landmark community celebration commemorating the city‚Äôs storied past and vibrant present. The festivities will take place on Friday, August 22, 2025, at 7:30 p.m. in the heart of Waxahachie at Railyard Park.

Honoring Our Heritage

Founded in 1850, Waxahachie has grown from a small settlement along the Waxahachie Creek into a thriving city renowned for its historic charm, warm community spirit, and rich cultural heritage. As we mark 175 years, we celebrate not only our remarkable history but also the neighbors, partners, and supporters who make Waxahachie such a wonderful place to call home.

Event Highlights

  • Community Art Project: Experience the creativity of Waxahachie firsthand! Our collaborative community art installation, featuring works by local artists and residents, will be on display throughout the evening.
  • Hear from Mayor Billie Wallace and Interim City Manager Ricky Boyd
  • Historic Walking Tour: Dive into the city‚Äôs fascinating past with a free Historic Walking Tour of Downtown Waxahachie. Self-guided tours can be walked before the main event‚Äîcome early and explore our treasured landmarks and stories. The walking tour will be available through the first week of September. 
  • Enjoy a DJ, kid activities, giveaways, and pick up an event t-shirt (benefiting the Ellis County Museum).
  • Spectacular Drone Show: As the sun sets, look to the skies for a dazzling drone show, illuminating the night with a tribute to Waxahachie‚Äôs journey through the ages.

Thank You to Our Sponsors

This milestone event would not be possible without the generous support of our sponsors, whose commitment helps us bring the community together in celebration. Thank you to all our local businesses, organizations, and volunteers for making this event a reality.

  • Citizens National Bank of Texas ‚Äì proud sponsor of the drone show
  • H-E-B Waxahachie ‚Äì providing complimentary cupcakes
  • Americase, LLC ‚Äì event shirt sponsor (proceeds will benefit the Ellis County Museum)
  • Altus Emergency Centers Waxahachie - proudly sponsoring the community art project

Additional community sponsors helping to make this a fantastic event include Historic Waxahachie Inc., Ellis County Museum, Inc., N. P. Sims Library, Waxahachie ISD, Waxahachie Family YMCA, Fresh Market Coffee, Southern Roots Brewing Company, and Railport Brewing Company.

Plan Your Evening Downtown

We encourage everyone to arrive early, find parking, and take advantage of all that Downtown Waxahachie has to offer. Enjoy dinner or a drink at one of our many fantastic restaurants and bars before making your way to Railyard Park for an unforgettable evening of fun, history, and community spirit.

Whether you‚Äôre a lifelong resident or a first-time visitor, the 175th Birthday Bash is the perfect opportunity to connect with friends, family, and neighbors while honoring the legacy and bright future of Waxahachie. Mark your calendars for August 22, 2025, at 7:30 p.m. at Railyard Park. We can‚Äôt wait to celebrate with you!

Jul 14, 2025

CHIEF RICKY BOYD NAMED INTERIM CITY MANAGER

The Waxahachie City Council decided on Monday, July 7, to separate the employment of City Manager Michael Scott, effective immediately. Mr. Scott began his career with the City in 2002. He served in numerous leadership roles, including Downtown Director, Director of Planning, Assistant City Manager, and, most recently, as City Manager since 2017. His commitment and contributions to our community over more than two decades have left a lasting impact, and we extend our sincere gratitude for his years of service. 

As we move forward, on Friday, July 11, the City Council voted unanimously to appoint Fire Chief Ricky Boyd as interim city manager to ensure a seamless transition and continued excellence in city operations. Chief Boyd has been with the City of Waxahachie for 13 years and has served for over 40 years in the fire service.

We are confident in the abilities of our leadership team and staff to maintain the high standards our residents expect and deserve. The City of Waxahachie remains united and focused on our shared vision for the future. We are committed to transparency, stability, and progress as we continue to serve our citizens with integrity and dedication. Together, we look forward to building on our strong foundation and advancing the interests of our vibrant community.

Jun 24, 2025

27TH ANNUAL CRAPE MYRTLE FESTIVAL, FIREWORKS & PARADE
Please see the tips below for a fun and stress-free holiday as you attend the Crape Myrtle Festival, Parade, and Fireworks Show.

July 3: Crape Myrtle Festival & Fireworks Show
Arrive early: Gates open at 5 PM. The party starts at 6 PM, and the concert starts at 7:30 PM. Fireworks will begin at 9:15 PM. Spectators can tune their radio to KBEC 1390AM/99.1 FM during the fireworks show for a special simulcast of patriotic music choreographed to the fireworks.

* Entry and exit points are clearly marked on the map at Park Place Blvd. and Broadhead Road. Please drive carefully and watch for pedestrians.


Parking: Parking will be available at the lot near the football, track, and volleyball fields, as noted on the map. There will be no parking near the soccer fields.

Free admission: The festival will take place at the Waxahachie Sports Complex, located at 151 Broadhead Road.

What to expect: Food trucks, free kid zone, live music, vendors, and a fireworks show.

What to bring: Lawn chairs, blankets, and coolers are allowed at the Sports Complex, however, personal fireworks are prohibited.

*Personal fireworks are prohibited.



July 4: Crape Myrtle 4th of July Parade

Arrive early: The parade will begin at 10 a.m. at Getzendaner Park; proceed north on Grand, east (right) on Main Street, south (right) on S. Rogers Street, and will end at the historic train depot.

Road closures: The parade route, including the viaduct bridge, will close at 9:30 a.m. Please be on site before this time and follow all traffic and detour signs.

Parking: Main Street, Water Street, and Jefferson Street will be closed, and no parking will be allowed. Spectators are encouraged to utilize downtown parking and the Parking Garage.

Restrooms: Restrooms are available at Getzendaner Park, located at 400 S. Grand. Temporary restrooms will also be available.

Getzendaner Park: The park will be closed to all vehicle traffic on July 4 until the parade traffic has been cleared out. The park is open to pedestrians.



For more information about the Crape Myrtle Festival, please visit the Convention and Visitors Bureau website at https://www.waxahachiecvb.com/.

WAXAHACHIE WELCOMES LEADERSHIP RENEWAL AT SPECIAL CITY COUNCIL MEETING

It‚Äôs a great day in Waxahachie! During a Special City Council meeting on Monday, May 12, Mayor Billie Wallace (Place 4) and Councilman Travis Smith (Place 5) were officially sworn in, continuing their dedicated service to the community for another two years.

The City Council unanimously supported Mayor Billie Wallace's continuation in her role. In addition, Councilman Patrick Souter was voted Mayor Pro Tem, ensuring strong leadership and collaboration within the council as they work towards shaping the future of Waxahachie.

‚ÄúWe are thrilled to continue serving the residents of Waxahachie,‚Äù said Mayor Wallace. ‚ÄúThis community is filled with potential. I look forward to working alongside the rest of our council to promote our community‚Äôs values for all our citizens.‚Äù

Looking Ahead
Under the leadership of Mayor Wallace and the newly appointed Mayor Pro Tem Souter, the City Council aims to enhance community engagement, improve infrastructure, and foster economic growth. Their commitment to transparency and collaboration will guide their initiatives over the next two years.

May 06, 2025

ELITE RATING PLACES WAXAHACHIE AMONG TOP-TIER FIRE DEPARTMENTS NATIONWIDE
The City of Waxahachie is proud to announce that the Waxahachie Fire-Rescue Department has achieved an ISO Class 1 rating, the highest possible score awarded by the Insurance Services Office (ISO). This prestigious designation places Waxahachie Fire-Rescue in an elite category, as fewer than 1% of fire departments across the nation earn this distinction.

The ISO rating is a comprehensive evaluation that assesses a fire department's ability to respond effectively to emergencies and protect life and property. The rating system, known as the Public Protection Classification (PPC), measures several critical elements, including a department's staffing, training, equipment, facilities, water supply systems, and emergency communication capabilities.

"This is a citywide accomplishment," said Waxahachie Fire Chief Ricky Boyd. "It takes a collaborative effort between all city departments, and support from our City Council as well as the City Manager and the rest of the City‚Äôs Staff, to earn a perfect rating. I especially commend our staff for their dedication and commitment to providing the citizens of Waxahachie with superior fire protection. Waxahachie Fire-Rescue is committed to continuing its efforts to maintain the ISO 1 Classification for years to come.‚Äù

Visit the Waxahachie Fire-Rescue ISO Page to learn how this new classification benefits the community.

May 01, 2025

CITY OF WAXAHACHIE EARNS 2024 TREE CITY USA RECOGNITION

The Arbor Day Foundation named the City of Waxahachie a 2024 Tree City USA in honor of its commitment to plant, grow, and maintain trees to benefit its community.

The Arbor Day Foundation is a global nonprofit with a mission to inspire people to plant, nurture and celebrate trees. Its network of more than a million supporters and partners has helped the organization plant more than 500 million trees in forests and communities across more than 60 countries since 1972. The Tree City USA program has recognized cities and towns that leverage urban forestry to enhance the livability and sustainability of their local area for over 50 years.

‚ÄúWe all have a role to play in shaping our future and tree champions like Waxahachie are leading the way,‚Äù said Michelle Saulnier, Vice President of Programs at the Arbor Day Foundation. ‚ÄúTrees are critical infrastructure, building resiliency and fostering good health in our nation‚Äôs cities. We‚Äôre proud Waxahachie is among the Arbor Day Foundation‚Äôs growing network of communities dedicated to creating positive impact through trees.‚Äù  

In cities and neighborhoods, trees are proven to help mitigate the urban heat island effect, reduce stormwater runoff, improve air quality, and boost mental and physical health. When the right trees are planted in the right places, they can also reduce traffic noise, increase property values, and lower energy costs for homeowners.  

‚ÄúBeing part of Tree City USA is a testament to the City's commitment to creating a healthy environment for our residents.  I am proud to be part of an organization prioritizing nature and sustainability, said Chris Seale, City of Waxahachie Horticulturist.

To earn Tree City USA recognition, a city must uphold four core standards including maintaining a tree board or department, having a community tree ordinance, spending at least $2 per capita on urban forestry, and participating in an Arbor Day celebration. 

The Arbor Day Foundation‚Äôs Tree City USA program is operated in partnership with the National Association of State Foresters and the USDA Forest Service.  To learn more about the program or how to apply, visit arborday.org.

Read More
Apr 08, 2025

MAYOR WALLACE RECOGNIZED AT CITY COUNCIL MEETING

Mayor Billie Wallace was recognized at the City Council meeting on Monday, April 7, for recertifying her Certified Municipal Official (CMO) designation. She was officially recognized on Thursday, March 20, at the Texas Municipal League (TML) Midyear Conference in Austin, Texas.

The CMO Program, offered by the Texas Municipal League (TML), recognizes elected city officials in Texas who commit to ongoing professional development. To earn the CMO designation, officials must complete 60 Continuing Education Units (CEUs) within two consecutive years, including at least 30 CEUs from in-person training and 1 CEU each in five core competency areas: Ethics, Finance, Governance, Open Meetings, and Public Information.

Training can be obtained through TML-sponsored events, such as conferences and workshops, and must be related to municipal leadership. The program requires regular CEU submissions and awards an official who meets the criteria a certificate, pin, and recognition at TML events. To maintain certification, officials must complete 15 CEUs annually, including in-person training and core areas.

The City of Waxahachie applauds Mayor Wallace's commitment to professional development and her continued success as a CMO. Her dedication to ongoing education sets an inspiring example for other council members to follow.

Apr 07, 2025

We‚Äôre making it easier than ever to request public records!

Starting Monday, April 7, the City of Waxahachie and the Waxahachie Police Department are launching JustFOIA, a new and improved system for submitting and tracking public records requests. This user-friendly platform will streamline the process, ensuring transparency and efficiency for our community.

Apr 01, 2025

VENDOR OPPORTUNITY FOR WEBSITE DESIGN AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES
Vendor Opportunity!

The City of Waxahachie is seeking qualified vendors to provide comprehensive website design and development services. The goal of this project is to develop a modern, user-friendly, and accessible website that accurately reflects the organization‚Äôs mission and effectively meets the needs of its citizens and stakeholders.

Interested vendors are encouraged to contact the communications department at comms@waxahachie.com or via phone at 469-309-4012, no later than Friday, April 18.

Scope of work for this project will include but is not limited to:

Website Design
    • Develop a visually appealing, modern, and responsive design.
    • Ensure the design aligns with the organization's branding and mission.
    • Incorporate user-friendly navigation and intuitive interfaces.
Website Development
    • Build a secure, scalable, and fast-loading website.
    • Ensure compatibility across all major browsers, devices, and integration of existing software.
    • Integrate features such as search functionality, online forms, and interactive elements.
Accessibility and Compliance
    • Ensure full compliance with WCAG 2.2 Level AA standards for accessibility and include ongoing updates as the guidelines change.
    • Implement multilingual support if required.
Content Migration
    • Migrate existing content from the current website to the new platform.
    • Optimize and organize content for clarity and ease of access.
Testing and Quality Assurance
    • Conduct thorough testing for performance, security, and usability.
    • Address bugs and issues before launch.
Training and Documentation
    • Provide training for organizational staff on how to update and manage the website.
    • Deliver detailed documentation for ongoing maintenance.
Ongoing Support and Maintenance 
    • Include a proposal for post-launch support and updates.
    • Identify staff who will provide ongoing support to the organization.

Mar 31, 2025

DRONE DELIVERIES TO BEGIN IN WAXAHACHIE SOON

 Zipline drone deliveries are expected to begin in Waxahachie in the coming weeks.

According to Zipline, the Dallas-Fort Worth metro area is leading the country in quiet, fast, and convenient aerial delivery. Areas across the metroplex, like Garland, Frisco, and Denton, already offer similar services, and later this year, this innovative form of delivery will arrive in Waxahachie!

Zipline, the world's largest autonomous delivery system, will bring its ultra-fast, quiet delivery service to the Waxahachie Walmart later this year.

When it starts operating, Zipline will deliver thousands of items from the Walmart on 1200 N Highway 77 to residents in the area. Zipline aircraft are quieter than passing cars and are designed for safety and privacy.


In preparation, Zipline will conduct a few calibration and validation flights with a small group of residents before officially launching. Over the coming weeks, residents in this area may occasionally notice flights by Zipline's aircraft. These operations will only occur during business hours and are part of Zipline's rigorous safety and operational protocols to ensure a great experience when they begin serving our community.

You should know that Zipline designs and manufactures its aircraft to optimize for safe, quiet, convenient deliveries. These aircraft are not like agricultural, videography, or consumer drones, and are instead equipped with many advanced safety features and privacy protections to ensure a reliable and community-friendly experience.

 The City has communicated with Zipline to ensure all activities comply with FAA regulations.

If you have questions about this exciting new service, please contact Zipline directly at DFW@flyzipline.com .

FARMERS MARKET GRAND OPENING APRIL 5, 2025

The Waxahachie Farmers Market Returns for the 2025 Season!

The Waxahachie Farmers Market is back for the Spring/Summer season, and we're kicking things off in a big way!  Mark your calendars‚Äîthe season kicks off on Saturday, April 5, at 701 Howard Rd.

Opening Day Special!
Be one of the first 100 customers and receive a FREE canvas tote bag (one per family‚Äîwhile supplies last).

Live Music by Khoury Moore!
Enjoy the sounds of Khoury Moore as he sets the perfect Saturday morning vibe while you shop.

Meet the Mini Herefords! 
Swing by our Educational Corral to see the Mini Herefords! These adorable cattle are still getting used to all the attention, so while petting won't be available, you‚Äôll still get to admire them up close. 
*Weather permitting.

Shop Local, Eat Fresh!
Join us every Saturday from 8 AM to 1 PM to discover farm-fresh produce, handmade goods, and delicious local favorites.

New & Returning Vendors!
This season, we‚Äôre excited to welcome new vendors while bringing back the familiar faces you love. Explore fresh finds, connect with local artisans, and support our amazing community businesses!

For a complete list of vendors, please visit the Farmers Market page at www.waxahachie.com/FarmersMarket.

See you at the market!

CITY OFFICES CLOSED ON GOOD FRIDAY APRIL 18, 2025

The City of Waxahachie will be closed on Friday, April 18, in observance of Good Friday.

As a reminder, trash service will pick up on your scheduled day unless it is Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, or New Year's Day. All other holidays will have a regularly scheduled trash service.

Jan 31, 2025

2024 WAXAHACHIE POLICE DEPARTMENT AWARDS BANQUET

It was a night to remember for many Waxahachie Police officers, staff, and their families who attended the Waxahachie Police Department Annual Awards Banquet held on Wednesday, January 29, at the Waxahachie Civic Center. Approximately 80 awards were presented to deserving police officers, police department staff, City staff, and community members. Award categories ranged from Certificate of Merit to the Lifesaving Award, Civilian of the Year, and Officer of the Year.

Chief Joe Wiser welcomed a crowd of over 250 attendees. ‚ÄúThe Awards Banquet continues to be one of the most enjoyable nights of the year for me. I am truly honored to recognize the outstanding team and community members I have the privilege to work with daily,‚Äù stated Chief Wiser.

The City of Waxahachie would like to congratulate each of the 2024 award recipients. ‚ÄúIt is no secret that Waxahachie is a special place, and it is staff and community members like those we recognized at the banquet who help to keep it that way,‚Äù said City Manager Michael Scott. I am constantly amazed by what our police force and community members can achieve, and I am grateful we can come together to celebrate their service.

The top honors went to Christian Garcia for Officer of the Year, Sgt. Dustin Koch for Supervisor of the Year, Sue Clark for Dispatcher of the Year, and David Bittle for Civilian of the Year.

2024 Waxahachie Police Department Award Recipients

Selected by their peers, the WPD Annual Awards are presented to individuals who reflect the highest standards of conduct for law enforcement officers or support staff in their prospective positions.

Jan 24, 2024

ELECTED OFFICIALS TO BE RECOGNIZED BY THE TMLI

The City of Waxahachie is honored to announce that Mayor David Hill will be recognized for earning the Certified Municipal Official designation and Award of Excellence on March 15, at the Texas Municipal League Midyear Conference in San Marcos, Texas.

An elected official who completes 72 or more Continuing Education Units (CEUs) in one calendar year obtains the Certified Municipal Official designation. This state-required training covers topics including the Open Meetings Act and Public Information Act.

An Award of Excellence is earned when an elected official receives this recognition for five consecutive years. Additionally, the City of Waxahachie will receive an Award of Leadership as a result of Mayor Hill‚Äôs Award of Excellence accomplishment.  

‚ÄúIt is gratifying to see our elected officials be recognized for their remarkable dedication and service to the Waxahachie community,‚Äù said City Manager Michael Scott. ‚ÄúThe knowledge that this education provides is invaluable to our citizens.‚Äù

Councilmember Billie Wallace will also be recognized at the conference with a Certificate of Recognition for successful completion of 42 or more CEUs in a calendar year.

 
Mayor David Hill


Councilmember Billie Wallace

Jan 10, 2024

CITY ROLLS OUT NEW ELECTRONIC BIDDING SYSTEM

The City of Waxahachie has partnered with OpenGov and is excited to announce our transition from a paper-based bid solicitation process to a fully automated, web-based electronic bidding and vendor management system. 

Our new e-Procurement Portal will allow interested parties to do the following:

  • Register to bid and receive notifications of future opportunities in the e-Procurement Portal by selecting Subscribe to create an account.
  • Follow updates to existing solicitations by finding the solicitation and clicking the Follow button. This will allow all interested parties to receive solicitation updates automatically.
  • Submit questions and receive answers for open solicitations.
  • Guide vendors through the process of responding electronically to RFPs, bids, etc. to ensure submissions have been accurately completed.
  • Ultimately, be your prime location for all bid opportunities issued by the City of Waxahachie.
For more information, please click HERE. Read More
Jan 09, 2024

WATER CONSERVATION LOWERED TO STAGE 2
 As of January 9, 2024, Waxahachie is now in Stage 2 of the City‚Äôs Water Conservation Plan. While at Stage 2 we are not yet under mandatory restrictions, Citizens are strongly encouraged to conserve water and reduce all non-essential water use. This plan, also referred to as the Drought Contingency Plan, was adopted in 2019 by City Council as a proactive measure to help conserve our community‚Äôs water supply, especially in the case of severe drought.

Each of the plan levels are listed below, along with what each level entails. We are currently at Stage 2.

Stage 1: No formal restrictions, however citizens are encouraged to refrain from outdoor watering between 10am to 6pm, the hottest hours of the day.
Stage 2: (WE ARE CURRENTLY HERE) Customers are encouraged to conserve water, and reduce all non-essential water use.
Stage 3: Mandatory limits on lawn and landscape watering will be enacted, and water use will be limited to certain defined days of the week.
Stage 4: Mandatory water restrictions will be strengthened to Saturday only from 4am to 10am.
Stage 5: Mandatory water restrictions will be strengthened to prohibit watering of commercial lawns and landscapes.

Please note that most of these stages are unlikely, however we do have a plan in place should extreme conditions ever arise. We hope this information helps clarify our Water Conservation Plan, and we thank each of our residents for helping do their part!

Read More

CITY CLOSED FOR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. DAY
City Hall will be closed on Monday, January 15 in observance of Martin Luther King Jr. Day. For non-emergency needs during this time, please call the Waxahachie Police Department at 469-309-4400. For emergencies, please dial 911. Have a safe and happy holiday!
